markdownRemark.html:
What is the output of:

['1', '2', '3'].map(parseInt);

I came across this question during a job interview.

Obviously, this was a tricky question. It is easy to presume that the result would be an array like [1, 2, 3] (like I did). However, that’s not the case.

If you type the expression into the console in your browser, you’ll get the result below:

[1, NaN, NaN]

But why?

After reading Allen Wirfs-Brock’s blog, I got the answer.

According to the ECMAScript 5 Specification

frontmatter.title: Tricky parseInt()
frontmatter.description: A tricky use case of Array.map() and parseInt()
